channel.title: Virtualization across a few computers
channel.description:
Or cloud computing. I want to know the drawbacks. I'm seriously thinking about trying this idea unless there's a good reason not to.
Anyone remember Helmer, the 24-core setup in the IKEA Helmer cabinet? I'd build something very similar if not the same thing just up to date. The big difference is that I would use something like Eucalyptus to create one computer scaled across all of them, having 24 cores and 96GB of RAM. I'm interesting in what I would need to do to cut down on network time between the machines.
I want to do this because having many computers is not an issue for me, it's having many licenses to many programs for each one. Although, each rendering license can be bought as an "unlimited core" license that can be used on one computer with X amount of cores. They do this to stay future sighted.

item.title: Virtualization across a few computers
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

ffmpeg is free and open source, I’d suggest you try to consolidate your processing on that so you don’t have to go through all this ridiculousness.

But anyway, I’m guessing you are going for something like this:
http://helmer.sfe.se/
? I think that is what you referenced in your first post.

I’d say just google around for other people that have done similar things and wrote anything up about them, like this dated article:
http://tldp.org/HOWTO/Cluster-HOWTO.html

The only problem I think you might run into is running windows programs on it, I’m sure you can run Windows with KVM inside the cluster, but I don’t know if windows will support all that memory and CPU cores, and how well it will work. For running Linux applications I’m sure everything will work perfectly.

item.title: Virtualization across a few computers
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

After Effects would be the only one that would have to be run via Windows. Other than that, The Foundry’s Nuke, Pixar’s Renderman Pro Server, Mental Ray, and ffmpeg.

The way everything works now is that we have many quad-core machines that each would need a quad-core license to render. We need as much power as we can get. The real motivator is that you have to buy a dual, quad, or unlimited license per machine.

With this, we would be running all those machines as one or two massive machines, thus only needed two unlimited core licenses.
